Name: Indo-European (Bouckaert et al. 2012)
Author: Bouckaert
Reference: Bouckaert, R. R., Lemey, P., Dunn, M., Greenhill, S. J., Alekseyenko, A. V, Drummond, A. J., Gray, R. D., Suchard, M. A., & Atkinson, Q. D. (2012). Mapping the Origins and Expansion of the Indo-European Language Family. Science, 337(6097), 957-960.

Name: Pama-Nyungen (Bowern and Atkinson 2012)
Author: Bowern & Atkinson
Reference: Bowern, C., & Atkinson, Q. D. (2012). Computational phylogenetics and the internal structure of Pama-Nyungan. Language, 88(4), 817-845.

Name: Uto-Aztecan (Dunn et al. 2011)
Author: Dunn et al.
Reference: Dunn, M., Greenhill, S. J., Levinson, S. C., & Gray, R. D. (2011). Evolved structure of language shows lineage-specific trends in word-order universals. Nature, 473(7345), 79-82.

Name: Austronesian (Gray et al. 2009)
Author: Gray et al.
Reference: Gray, R. D., Drummond, A. J., & Greenhill, S. J. (2009). Language phylogenies reveal expansion pulses and pauses in Pacific settlement. Science, 323(5913), 479-483.

Name: Bantu (Grollemund et al. 2015)
Author: Grollemund et al.
Reference: Grollemund, R., Branford, S., Bostoen, K., Meade, A., Venditti, C., & Pagel, M. (2015). Bantu expansion shows habitat alters the route and pace of human dispersals. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA, 112(43), 13296-13301.

Name: Semitic (Kitchen et al. 2009)
Author: Kitchen et al.
Reference: Kitchen, A., Ehret, C., Assefa, S., & Mulligan, C. J. (2009). Bayesian phylogenetic analysis of Semitic languages identifies an Early Bronze Age origin of Semitic in the Near East. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 270(1668), 2703-2710.

Name: Japonic (Lee & Hasegawa 2011)
Author: Lee & Hasegawa
Reference: Lee S, Hasegawa T (2011) Bayesian phylogenetic analysis supports an agricultural origin of Japonic languages. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 278(1725):3662–9.

Name: Tukanoan (Chacon & List 2015)
Author: Chacon & List
Reference: Chacon TC, List J-M (2015) Improved computational models of sound change shed light on the history of the Tukanoan languages. Journal of Language Relationship, 3:177–203.

Name: Dene-Yenesian (Sicoli & Holton 2014)
Author: Sicoli & Holton
Reference: Sicoli MA, Holton G (2014) Linguistic phylogenies support back-migration from Beringia to Asia. PLoS One 9(3):e91722.

Name: Tupi-Guarani (Michael et al. 2015)
Author: Michael et al.
Reference: Michael L, et al. (2015) A Bayesian Phylogenetic Classification of Tupi-Guarani. LIAMES 15(2):1–36.
